scenario:
Data shows that Prep Program A has a higher overall college acceptance rate than Prep Program B.
However, when acceptance rates are compared within family income brackets (low-income vs.
higher-income), Program B has higher acceptance rates in every bracket.
Program A serves a larger share of higher-income students, while Program B serves mostly
low-income students.
claim: Prep Program A is more effective at getting students into selective colleges.
label: NO
causal_structure:
Family income distribution (Z) differs between prep programs and strongly affects college
acceptance, producing a misleading aggregate comparison.
key_insight:
Different income composition can raise overall acceptance rates even when within-group
performance is worse.
hidden_timestamp: Was family income bracket known before students enrolled in Prep Program A vs. B, making it a true pre-enrollment stratifier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you rely only on overall acceptance rates, you would conclude that Prep Program A is more effective.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare acceptance rates within income brackets or standardize by income, Prep Program B performs better.

wise_refusal:
This is Simpson’s Paradox driven by composition. Program A enrolls more higher-income
students, who have higher baseline acceptance rates. That raises Program A’s overall
acceptance rate even though Program B performs better within every income bracket.
gold_rationale:
This case exhibits Simpson’s Paradox caused by aggregation bias.
Family income bracket (Z) strongly affects college acceptance (Y) and differs in distribution
between prep programs (X). Program A enrolls more higher-income students, which raises its
overall acceptance rate. However, within every income bracket, Program B has higher acceptance
rates. Therefore, Program A’s apparent advantage is driven by compositional differences rather
than superior effectiveness.
Conclusion: The claim “Prep Program A is more effective” is INVALID based on the aggregate data.

scenario: Bank X has a lower overall loan default rate than Bank Y. However, when borrowers are grouped by credit-risk tier (prime vs. subprime), Bank Y has a lower default rate in every tier.
claim: Bank X has better underwriting practices than Bank Y.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bank choice influences borrower risk composition, and borrower risk strongly affects default rates, producing a misleading aggregate comparison.
key_insight: Aggregate default rates reflect portfolio risk mix rather than underwriting quality.
hidden_timestamp: Is credit-risk tier determined prior to bank selection, making it a valid pre-treatment stratifier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you compare only overall default rates, you would conclude that Bank X has better underwriting.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare default rates within risk tiers or standardize by risk distribution, Bank Y performs better.

wise_refusal: This is Simpson’s Paradox. Bank X serves a larger share of prime borrowers, while Bank Y serves more subprime borrowers. The lower aggregate default rate reflects differences in borrower risk composition, not superior underwriting quality.
gold_rationale: This case exhibits Simpson’s Paradox driven by portfolio composition. Credit-risk tier (Z) strongly affects loan default (Y) and differs in distribution across banks (X). Although Bank X has a lower overall default rate, Bank Y has lower default rates within every risk tier. Therefore, Bank X’s apparent advantage is due to risk mix rather than better underwriting. Conclusion: The claim “Bank X has better underwriting practices” is INVALID based on the aggregate data alone.

scenario: Clinic A has a lower overall 30-day readmission rate than Clinic B. However, when patients are grouped by age (under 65 vs. 65+), Clinic B has lower readmission rates in both age groups.
claim: Clinic A provides better follow-up care than Clinic B.
label: NO
causal_structure: Clinic choice is associated with patient age composition, and age strongly affects readmission risk, leading to a misleading aggregate comparison.
key_insight: Aggregate readmission rates reflect patient age mix rather than quality of follow-up care.
hidden_timestamp: Is patient age determined prior to clinic assignment, making it a valid pre-treatment stratifier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you rely only on overall readmission rates, you would conclude that Clinic A provides better follow-up care.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare readmission rates within age groups or standardize by age distribution, Clinic B performs better.

wise_refusal: This is Simpson’s Paradox. Clinic A treats a larger share of younger patients, while Clinic B treats more older patients. The lower aggregate readmission rate reflects differences in patient age mix, not superior follow-up care.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates Simpson’s Paradox caused by age-based case mix. Patient age (Z) strongly affects readmission risk (Y) and differs in distribution across clinics (X). Although Clinic A has a lower overall readmission rate, Clinic B has lower readmission rates within both age groups. Therefore, Clinic A’s apparent advantage is compositional rather than causal. Conclusion: The claim “Clinic A provides better follow-up care” is INVALID based on the aggregate comparison alone.

scenario: A company reports that 85% of employees are satisfied based on responses to an anonymous satisfaction survey. Only 30% of employees responded. Some employees may be less likely to respond if they are dissatisfied or fear retaliation.
claim: Company morale is high.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z affects response and satisfaction; conditioning on responders yields biased satisfaction estimate.
key_insight: Survey results can be unrepresentative when response is selective.
hidden_timestamp: Did dissatisfaction exist before employees chose whether to respond, or did the survey context change willingness to respond?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If survey response is unrelated to satisfaction, the sample may reflect overall morale accurately.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If dissatisfied employees are less likely to respond, the reported satisfaction rate is biased upward.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer company-wide morale without response-rate patterns and information about non-respondents.
gold_rationale:
Selection bias via sampling-on-the-outcome: only responders are observed.
 If dissatisfied employees respond less, the observed satisfaction rate overestimates true satisfaction.
 Conclusion: The claim “morale is high company-wide” is INVALID from respondent-only data.

scenario: A blog analyzes film profitability using only movies that won major awards. Award-winning films tend to have high budgets, leading the author to conclude that increasing budgets causes higher profits. The dataset excludes non-nominated and unsuccessful films.
claim: Higher budgets cause higher film profits.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (award inclusion) selects a non-representative subset; X–Y relationship differs from full population.
key_insight: Analyzing only visible successes distorts relationships between inputs and outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Is award status determined before profits are realized, or is the dataset effectively filtered after outcomes are known?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if awards are unrelated to profit (unlikely): Restriction would be less problematic.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if awards filter on quality/visibility correlated with profit: Include all films to avoid selection bias.

wise_refusal: I can’t draw a causal conclusion without data on non-award films and a clear sampling frame that includes both successes and failures.
gold_rationale:
Selection bias: conditioning on award status creates a selected sample.
Awards correlate with many factors and exclude failures, so the remaining sample is not representative.
 Conclusion: The claim “bigger budgets cause higher profits” is INVALID from award-winner-only data.

scenario: A city reports that participants who completed a workforce training program saw a 20% wage increase. Forty percent of enrollees dropped out and are excluded from the analysis.
claim: The training program increased participant earnings.
label: NO
causal_structure: Completion is selected post-enrollment; completers differ from dropouts in factors affecting Y.
key_insight: Attrition can make observed improvements unrepresentative of the full enrolled group.
hidden_timestamp: Did dropout occur after participants could have benefited (or been harmed) by the program, making completion a post-treatment selection?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dropout is random, completer outcomes may approximate average effects.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If dropouts had lower gains, analyzing only completers overstates impact.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate overall impact without outcomes (or credible imputations) for dropouts and evidence about why participants left.
gold_rationale:
Attrition bias: outcomes are observed only for completers.
 If dropouts would have had lower gains, analyzing only completers overstates average improvement.
 Conclusion: The claim “participants gained 20%” is INVALID without accounting for missing outcomes.

scenario: Days with higher ice cream sales in city parks also have more reported minor injuries. A city analyst argues that ice cream vendors create unsafe conditions. Hot weather increases park attendance and ice cream sales.
claim: Ice cream sales by vendors cause park injuries.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z increases both X and Y; omitting Z yields misleading correlation.
key_insight: An omitted common cause can create a misleading association.
hidden_timestamp: Did temperature rise before both ice cream sales and injuries, suggesting a shared upstream cause?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if you control for temperature and attendance: The sales–injury correlation may disappear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if injuries rise on high-attendance days regardless of vendors: Vendor restriction is not justified by this correlation.

wise_refusal: I can’t conclude causality without controlling for weather/attendance and knowing how vendor permits are assigned.
gold_rationale:
Omitted-variable confounding: temperature/attendance (Z) increases both sales (X) and injuries (Y).
 Correlation can appear even if vendors do not affect injuries.
 Conclusion: The claim “ice cream sales cause injuries” is INVALID from the raw correlation.

scenario: A hospital audit reports that patients prescribed a stronger painkiller have a higher 30-day mortality rate than patients prescribed a milder painkiller. A supervisor argues that the stronger drug is dangerous. Clinicians explain that the stronger painkiller is typically reserved for patients with more severe underlying conditions, who already face a substantially higher baseline risk of death. Patients with milder conditions are usually prescribed weaker medication or treated as outpatients.
claim: The stronger painkiller increases patient mortality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Illness severity influences both painkiller prescribing decisions and mortality risk.
key_insight: Higher mortality reflects patient severity, not the danger of the stronger medication.
hidden_timestamp: Was illness severity assessed before the prescribing decision, making it a true baseline confounder?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If patients with similar severity levels are compared, the apparent mortality difference may disappear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If severity is not adequately measured or adjusted for, residual confounding will bias the comparison.

wise_refusal: Comparing raw mortality rates across medications ignores differences in baseline patient severity. Without severity-adjusted analysis, the observed association cannot be interpreted as a causal drug effect.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates confounding by indication. Patients receiving stronger painkillers are systematically sicker and therefore at higher risk of death regardless of medication choice. The observed mortality difference reflects patient selection rather than a harmful effect of the stronger drug. Conclusion: the claim that the stronger painkiller increases mortality is INVALID based on this observational comparison alone.

scenario: A health system introduced telemedicine visits in some clinics while others stayed in-person only. A summary report claims telemedicine reduced follow-up adherence because telemedicine clinics show a lower overall rate of patients completing a recommended follow-up within 30 days. The evaluation compares 30-day follow-up completion rate in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Telemedicine reduces follow-up adherence
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Stratum imbalance can make an intervention look harmful overall even if it helps in every subgroup (or vice versa).
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel determined before adoption of the intervention (pre-treatment), making it legitimate to stratify on?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you use only the overall treated vs. untreated difference, you may draw the wrong causal conclusion because treated units are concentrated in harder (or easier) strata.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare within each baseline chronic-disease burden stratum or standardize, this addresses the imbalance and yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the intervention’s effect without knowing the rollout rule and verifying overlap in baseline chronic-disease burden between treated and untreated units.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention (Stratified Intervention Reversal). Z is a baseline stratifier that affects Y, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X). The aggregate treated-vs-untreated comparison conflates treatment effect with stratum composition. Use within-stratum comparisons and/or standardize to a common Z distribution. Conclusion: The aggregate causal claim is INVALID without stratification/standardization; the correct answer is CONDITIONAL on adjusting for Z.

scenario: A district piloted an after-school tutoring app in some middle schools. The district claims the app lowered math performance because app schools have lower average end-of-year math scores than non-app schools. The evaluation compares average end-of-year math score in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by baseline student achievement level (higher vs. lower prior-year scores), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: The tutoring app lowered math performance
label: NO

Z: Baseline student achievement level (higher vs. lower prior-year scores)

causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Stratum imbalance can make an intervention look harmful overall even if it helps in every subgroup.
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline student achievement level determined before adoption of the intervention, making it legitimate to stratify on?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using only the overall treated vs. untreated difference risks a wrong causal conclusion because treated schools are concentrated in harder strata.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Comparing within baseline achievement strata or standardizing addresses the imbalance and yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the intervention’s effect without knowing the rollout rule and verifying overlap in baseline student achievement between treated and untreated units.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention. Baseline achievement affects outcomes, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X). The aggregate comparison conflates treatment effect with composition.

scenario: A police department deployed body cameras in some precincts first. City leaders claim body cameras increased misconduct because camera precincts show higher overall citizen complaint rates than non-camera precincts during the evaluation period. The evaluation compares citizen complaint rates in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by baseline complaint environment of the precinct (historically high vs. low complaint rate), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Body cameras increased misconduct
label: NO

Z: Baseline complaint environment (historically high vs. low)

causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Targeting high-risk precincts can make reforms look harmful in aggregate even if they help everywhere.
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline complaint environment determined before body camera adoption?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using only aggregate differences risks attributing higher complaints to cameras rather than baseline risk concentration.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-stratum comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the effect without knowing rollout rules and overlap in baseline complaint environments.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention. Precinct risk environment affects complaints, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X).

scenario: A city offered subsidized monthly transit passes at certain large worksites. A memo claims the subsidy increased commute times because subsidized sites show longer average commutes than non-subsidized sites. The evaluation compares average door-to-door commute time in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by home-to-work distance category (short vs. long), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Transit subsidies increased commute times
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Weighted averages can reverse within-group improvements when exposure differs by difficulty.
hidden_timestamp: Was home-to-work distance determined before subsidy adoption?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using aggregate differences confounds subsidy effects with distance composition.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-distance comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the subsidy’s effect without knowing rollout rules and overlap in distance categories.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention. Commute distance affects time, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X).

When results are stratified by issue complexity level (simple vs. complex tickets), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. claim: The chatbot reduced customer satisfaction
label: NO

Z: Issue complexity level (simple vs. complex tickets)

causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using only aggregate differences conflates chatbot effects with concentration in complex tickets.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-complexity comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the chatbot’s effect without knowing rollout rules and overlap in issue complexity.

scenario: A firm allowed remote work in certain teams first. Leadership claims remote work reduced productivity because remote-eligible teams show lower overall weekly output than teams that remained on-site. The evaluation compares weekly output per employee in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by role type (individual contributor vs. people manager), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Remote work reduced productivity
label: NO

Z: Role type (individual contributor vs. people manager)

causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Aggregate productivity depends on role composition, not just work mode.
hidden_timestamp: Was role type fixed before remote eligibility was granted?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Aggregate comparisons confound remote work effects with role mix differences.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-role comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

scenario: A region piloted a carbon fee in some municipalities. A headline article claims the carbon fee increased emissions because fee municipalities show higher overall per-capita emissions than non-fee municipalities after the pilot begins. The evaluation compares per-capita CO₂ emissions in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. When results are stratified by industrial intensity of the municipality (high vs. low share of heavy industry), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: The carbon fee increased emissions
label: NO

Z: Industrial intensity (high vs. low heavy industry share)

causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Policy effects can be masked by concentration in high-baseline emitters.
hidden_timestamp: Was industrial intensity determined before the carbon fee was adopted?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Aggregate comparisons confound carbon fee effects with industrial composition.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-intensity comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the carbon fee’s effect without knowing rollout rules and overlap in industrial intensity.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention. Industrial composition affects emissions, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X).

scenario: A university introduced an optional pass/fail grading policy in some gateway courses. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by course difficulty tier (hard vs. moderate), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Pass/fail grading reduced course completion
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
key_insight: Difficulty-weighted rollout can reverse aggregate effects.
hidden_timestamp: Was course difficulty tier determined before adoption of pass/fail grading?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using only aggregate completion rates risks attributing lower completion to pass/fail rather than concentration in harder courses.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-difficulty comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the effect of pass/fail grading without knowing rollout rules and overlap in course difficulty.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox under intervention. Course difficulty affects completion, and rollout created imbalance in P(Z|X).

scenario: A city offered emergency microgrants to small businesses in selected corridors. A press release claims the grants did not help because grant-recipient corridors show lower overall one-year business survival than corridors without grants. The evaluation compares one-year business survival rates in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected. When results are stratified by baseline business fragility (low vs. high pre-grant revenue volatility), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within each stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
claim: Emergency microgrants reduced business survival
label: NO

Z: Baseline business fragility (low vs. high revenue volatility)

causal_structure: Fragility (Z) affects survival (Y) and influenced grant targeting, creating imbalance in P(Z|X).
key_insight: Targeting fragile units can mask beneficial effects in aggregate.
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline business fragility measured before grant allocation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Aggregate comparisons confound grant effects with concentration among fragile businesses.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within-fragility comparison or standardization yields a more credible estimate.

wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the grant’s effect without knowing the targeting rule and overlap in baseline fragility.

scenario: A city raises the minimum wage and later observes a higher rate of restaurant closures than in neighboring cities that did not raise wages. Commentators claim the wage increase caused closures. The city that raised wages was already experiencing rapidly rising commercial rents and declining foot traffic due to major construction, both of which affect closure risk and also influenced the political push for wage reform.
claim: The minimum wage increase caused restaurant closures
label: NO

Z: Commercial rent pressure and foot traffic trends

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y; without blocking Z, the X–Y comparison is confounded.
key_insight: Policy adoption can correlate with underlying economic pressures.
hidden_timestamp: Were commercial rent pressure and foot traffic trends measured before the policy decision and did they influence both adoption and outcomes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the wage increase were randomly assigned or exogenous, differences in closures could be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the wage increase was targeted to cities already facing rising rents and declining foot traffic, the naive comparison is confounded.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the causal effect without a clear assignment rule and credible measurement and adjustment for Z.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Confounding. Economic pressures influenced both wage adoption and closures, leaving an unblocked backdoor path.

scenario: A district adopts a new reading curriculum in schools flagged as “at risk.” After one year, adopting schools have lower reading scores than non-adopting schools, and critics claim the curriculum harmed learning. Adoption was prioritized for schools with declining prior scores and higher poverty rates—factors that also predict future scores regardless of curriculum.
claim: The new reading curriculum harmed learning
label: NO

Z: Baseline performance trend and student poverty rate

causal_structure: Z influences both adoption and outcomes; treated schools start on different trajectories.
key_insight: Targeted interventions create treated groups that differ systematically from controls.
hidden_timestamp: Were baseline performance trends and poverty rates measured before adoption and did they influence assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If adoption were randomized or as-if random, score differences could be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If adoption targeted schools with declining performance and higher poverty, the naive comparison is confounded.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the causal effect without a clear assignment rule and credible adjustment for baseline trends and poverty.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Confounding. Baseline disadvantage influenced both curriculum adoption and future scores, leaving an unblocked backdoor path.

scenario: A federal grant funds community policing in selected neighborhoods. A year later, funded neighborhoods show higher reported crime than unfunded neighborhoods, leading to claims that the grants increased crime. Grant selection prioritized neighborhoods with historically high crime and recent upward trends, which also predict future crime.
claim: Community policing grants increased crime
label: NO

Z: Baseline crime level and pre-grant trend

causal_structure: Z affects both grant selection and crime outcomes, confounding causal interpretation.
key_insight: Comparing funded vs. unfunded neighborhoods conflates intervention effects with baseline risk.
hidden_timestamp: Were baseline crime levels and trends measured before grant selection and did they influence funding?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If funding were randomized, post-grant crime differences could be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If funding targeted high-crime, worsening areas, the naive comparison is confounded.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the causal effect without a clear assignment rule and credible measurement of baseline crime risk.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Confounding. Selection on need creates an unblocked backdoor path between funding and crime.

scenario: A grocery chain introduces front-of-package nutrition labels in some stores. Purchases of sugary snacks are higher in labeled stores, and an executive claims labels backfired. The chain piloted labels first in dense urban stores with distinct customer baskets and higher baseline snack purchases.
claim: Nutrition labels increased sugary snack purchases
label: NO

Z: Store neighborhood type and baseline basket patterns

causal_structure: Z affects both store selection for labeling and snack purchases, biasing naive comparisons.
key_insight: Rollout decisions can confound estimated behavioral impacts.
hidden_timestamp: Were neighborhood type and baseline basket patterns measured before rollout and did they influence store selection?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If labeling were randomly assigned to stores, differences could be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If labeling targeted urban stores with higher baseline snack demand, the naive comparison is confounded.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the causal effect without a clear assignment rule and credible adjustment for store-level confounders.

scenario: A company offers a hybrid-work stipend to certain teams and later observes higher turnover in stipend teams. Management claims hybrid work drives attrition. The stipend was offered first to teams undergoing reorganization and leadership turnover, which also increases attrition risk.
claim: Hybrid work causes higher employee turnover
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y; teams undergoing disruption are more likely to receive the stipend and to experience higher turnover.
key_insight: Interventions are often targeted to already-distressed units.
hidden_timestamp: Was team reorganization or leadership instability measured before the stipend decision?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stipend assignment was randomized (or as-if random), higher turnover may reflect a true effect of hybrid work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stipends were targeted to unstable teams, the higher turnover reflects confounding rather than a causal effect.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the causal effect without knowing whether team reorganization influenced both stipend assignment and turnover outcomes.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Confounding (Unblocked Backdoor). Z influences both X and Y, invalidating naive treated-versus-untreated comparisons unless Z is blocked.

scenario: A city expands protected bike lanes on selected commercial corridors and later sees lower retail sales on those corridors than on others. Critics claim bike lanes hurt businesses. Bike lanes were prioritized for corridors already facing construction disruption and declining sales trends.
claim: Protected bike lanes reduce retail sales
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y; struggling corridors are more likely to receive bike lanes and to have lower future sales.
key_insight: Infrastructure is often targeted to declining areas, confounding impact evaluations.
hidden_timestamp: Were construction disruption and declining sales trends observed before bike lane selection?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If corridor selection was randomized, post-expansion sales differences may reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If bike lanes were targeted to declining corridors, the observed sales drop is confounded.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer the effect of bike lanes on sales without knowing whether baseline disruption and decline influenced corridor selection.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Confounding. Targeting bike lanes to already struggling corridors leaves an unblocked backdoor path from Z to both X and Y.

scenario: A clinic increases outreach call frequency for patients who have not scheduled vaccinations. Later, patients who received more calls have lower vaccination rates, and a manager claims calls deter people. Call frequency rises when patients remain unvaccinated over time (past outcome), and those patients are harder to reach and less likely to vaccinate.
claim: Outreach calls deter vaccination uptake
label: NO
causal_structure: Past Y drives future X; past Y also predicts future Y.
key_insight: Reactive intensification of an intervention creates time-varying confounding.

scenario: A transit agency implements fare capping. Analysts compare satisfaction only among riders who took at least 20 trips per month and find lower satisfaction among capped-fare riders, concluding fare capping reduces satisfaction. High trip frequency is influenced by fare capping (making frequent riding cheaper) and by unobserved commuter dependence and route constraints, which also affect satisfaction.
claim: Fare capping reduces rider satisfaction
label: NO
causal_structure: X → C ← U → Y; conditioning on C opens X ↔ U, biasing X–Y within C=1.
key_insight: Conditioning on an intermediate participation/compliance variable can create spurious treatment–outcome relationships.
hidden_timestamp: Did compliance/participation (frequent rider (≥20 trips/month)) occur after assignment of X, making it a post-treatment variable affected by both X and U?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if U affects both compliance and outcomes: Conditioning on C induces collider bias; report intent-to-treat or avoid conditioning on C.

wise_refusal: I can’t make a causal claim from the compliant-only analysis without modeling why people become frequent rider (≥20 trips/month) and whether those determinants also affect Y.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Collider bias (Conditioning on Compliance): conditioning on high trip frequency biases the fare-capping effect estimate.

The evaluation compares conflict recurrence only among disputes that completed mediation sessions and finds higher recurrence when mediation was offered, concluding mediation worsens conflicts. Completion depends on mediation offer (providing a path to completion) and on unobserved conflict intensity and willingness to compromise, which also affects recurrence.
claim: Mediation worsens conflicts
label: NO

wise_refusal: I can’t make a causal claim from the compliant-only analysis without modeling why people become completed mediation and whether those determinants also affect Y.

scenario: A professor uses an automated plagiarism detector that flags 2% of submissions. The professor says, “If the system flags you, you basically plagiarized,” and proposes an automatic penalty policy. In reality, confirmed plagiarism is rare in this class, and the detector can produce false positives, especially on common template phrases.
claim: A detector flag means the student plagiarized
label: NO

Z: true plagiarism prevalence in the class

causal_structure: Observed signal is an imperfect measure of a rare underlying event; interpretation depends on prevalence and error rates.
key_insight: A positive flag can be misleading when the underlying event is rare and the test has false positives.
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate (true plagiarism prevalence in the class) and the detector’s false-positive/false-negative rates established before interpreting flagged cases?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if the base rate is high (event common) and false positives are low: A positive flag is more likely a true case.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if the base rate is low (event rare) or false positives are non-trivial: Many positives may be false; don’t equate “flagged” with “plagiarized.”

wise_refusal: I can’t infer “plagiarized” from a flag without the base rate and the detector’s accuracy; ignoring them risks major misinterpretation.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): the observed flag is a noisy proxy for true plagiarism, and predictive value depends on prevalence and error rates.

scenario: An airport runs passengers through a watchlist system and gets a small number of alerts. claim: A watchlist alert means the passenger is dangerous
label: NO

Z: prevalence of dangerous individuals among passengers

causal_structure: Observed signal is an imperfect measure of a rare underlying event; interpretation depends on prevalence and error rates.
key_insight: A positive alert can be misleading when the underlying condition is rare and false positives exist.
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate (prevalence of dangerous individuals) and the system’s false-positive/false-negative rates established before interpreting alerts?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if prevalence is high and false positives are low: An alert is strong evidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if prevalence is extremely low (typical) or false positives exist: Many alerts may be false; don’t treat alert as near-certain guilt.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer dangerousness from an alert without prevalence and accuracy parameters.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): alert status is a noisy indicator; predictive value depends on base rate and error rates.

label: NO

Z: prevalence of fraud among all transactions

causal_structure: Observed model flag is an imperfect measure of true fraud; predictive value depends on prevalence and error rates.
key_insight: A positive flag can be misleading when true fraud is rare and false positives exist.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if fraud prevalence is high and false positives are low: Flag likely indicates fraud.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer “almost always fraud” without prevalence and accuracy.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): the risk flag is a noisy proxy for fraud; predictive value depends on base rate and error rates.

scenario: A company offers screening for a rare disease. An employee tests positive and the HR office says, “A positive test means you probably have the disease,” and recommends immediate treatment. The disease is very rare in the workforce, and the test has non-zero false positives.
claim: A positive screening test means the employee has the disease
label: NO

Z: prevalence of the disease in the screened population

causal_structure: Test result is an imperfect measure of disease; posterior probability depends on base rate and test accuracy.
key_insight: When prevalence is low, many positives may be false even with a good test.
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate and sensitivity/specificity (false positives/negatives) established for this population?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if prevalence is high and specificity is high: A positive is strong evidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if prevalence is very low and specificity is imperfect: A positive may still be more likely false than true; confirmatory testing needed.

wise_refusal: I can’t interpret a single positive without prevalence and test accuracy; immediate treatment may be inappropriate.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): screening results require base rates and error rates to interpret.

label: NO

scenario: A workplace drug test is said to be “99% accurate.” Management argues that if a test is positive, the employee almost certainly used drugs. This reasoning uses the test’s accuracy as if it directly gave P(Drug use | Positive), without considering the base rate of drug use in the tested workforce.
claim: A positive drug test means the employee used drugs
label: NO
causal_structure: Test result is an imperfect measure; predictive value depends on prevalence and sensitivity/specificity, not just “accuracy.”
key_insight: Confusing test accuracy with P(use | positive) leads to overconfidence when base rates are low.
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate and false-positive/false-negative rates established for this workforce and test?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if drug use prevalence is high and false positives are rare: A positive is strong evidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if prevalence is low or false positives exist: A substantial fraction of positives may be false; confirmatory testing needed.

wise_refusal: I can’t conclude “almost certainly used drugs” from a positive without prevalence and error rates.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): interpreting a positive requires base rates and error rates, not overall accuracy alone.

scenario: A company receives an anonymous harassment report. A manager says, “Most real harassers get reported, so if someone is reported they are likely guilty.” This confuses the likelihood of a report given guilt with the probability of guilt given a report, and ignores how common false or ambiguous reports are relative to true cases.
claim: Being reported means the employee is guilty
label: NO

Z: prevalence of actual harassment among employees

causal_structure: Reports are an imperfect measure of true misconduct; predictive value depends on prevalence and reporting error rates.
key_insight: You can’t infer guilt from “most guilty get reported” without knowing false/ambiguous report rates and base prevalence.
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate of true harassment and the false/ambiguous report rate established?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if harassment is common and false reports are rare: A report is stronger evidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if harassment is rare or ambiguous/false reports are non-trivial: A report alone may not imply guilt; investigate.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer guilt from a report without base rates and reporting accuracy.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): “reported” is a noisy proxy for true harassment; predictive value depends on base rate and error rates.

scenario: A predictive policing tool labels a neighborhood as “high risk.” An official argues, “High-risk labels are accurate because most high-crime neighborhoods get labeled high risk.” This mixes up P(labeled | high crime) with P(high crime | labeled) and ignores how many neighborhoods receive labels relative to the true high-crime base rate.
claim: A high-risk label means the neighborhood is truly high-crime
label: NO

Z: base rate of truly high-crime neighborhoods

causal_structure: Label is an imperfect measure; predictive value depends on base rate and false positive/negative rates, not just sensitivity.
key_insight: High sensitivity (catching most true cases) does not imply high precision (most labeled are true).
hidden_timestamp: Were the base rate of truly high-crime neighborhoods and the tool’s false-positive/false-negative rates established?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if base rate is high and false positives are low: Label more likely true.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if base rate is low or false positives exist: Many labeled neighborhoods may not be truly high-crime.

wise_refusal: I can’t interpret “high risk” as “truly high crime” without base rates and error rates.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): model labels are noisy proxies; precision depends on prevalence and error rates.

scenario: An email filter catches “95% of spam.” A user claims that any email sent to spam is almost certainly spam and deletes the folder regularly. This uses P(sent to spam | spam) as if it were P(spam | sent to spam) and ignores the fraction of all emails that are spam and the false positive rate.
claim: An email sent to spam is almost certainly spam
label: NO

Z: base rate of spam among all incoming emails

causal_structure: Spam-folder assignment is an imperfect measure of true spam; predictive value depends on spam prevalence and false positives.
key_insight: High catch rate doesn’t imply that everything in spam is spam.
hidden_timestamp: Were the spam base rate and the filter’s false-positive/false-negative rates established?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if spam prevalence is high and false positives are very low: Most spam-folder emails are spam.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if prevalence is moderate/low or false positives exist: Some legitimate emails will be in spam; deleting without review risks loss.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer “almost certainly spam” without base rates and error rates.
gold_rationale: This is L2 Measurement (Misclassification): spam-folder placement is a noisy proxy; precision depends on prevalence and false positives.

scenario: A university evaluates an intensive college-success program. Some students participate and others do not. An analyst proposes estimating the program’s effect on graduation by comparing graduates among participants and non-participants, but only within the subset of students who report high academic confidence at the end of the first year. Academic confidence is measured after program participation.
claim: If students had not joined the intensive college-success program, they would have been less likely to graduate.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: X → M → Y, and conditioning on M mixes information across counterfactual worlds (cross-world bias).
key_insight: Conditioning on post-treatment variables to answer counterfactuals can create cross-world confounding.
hidden_timestamp: Does end-of-year academic confidence occur after X is assigned, meaning X can change M before Y is realized?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if end-of-year academic confidence is truly pre-treatment (not affected by X): Then conditioning could be appropriate (but verify timing).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if end-of-year academic confidence is influenced by X and affects Y: Do not condition on it for the total effect; redefine the question or use mediation methods with explicit assumptions.

wise_refusal: I can’t answer the counterfactual without clarifying whether end-of-year academic confidence is post-treatment and without specifying the target estimand (total effect vs. direct/mediated effects).
gold_rationale:
This is L3 Confounding (Cross-world Confounder).
 The proposed adjustment conditions on M, a post-intervention variable affected by X that also influences Y.
 In counterfactual terms, you cannot simultaneously fix M to the value it would take under X=1 and compare outcomes under X=0 without “cross-world” assumptions; conditioning on M can induce bias.
 Conclusion: The proposed counterfactual answer is INVALID; you need a valid causal estimand/design (e.g., total effect without conditioning on post-treatment M, or a properly defined mediation analysis with strong assumptions).

 Conclusion: The proposed counterfactual answer is INVALID; you need a valid causal estimand/design (e.g., total effect without conditioning on post-treatment M, or a properly defined mediation analysis with strong assumptions).

scenario: A county considers offering housing vouchers to low-income families. Policymakers propose estimating the effect of vouchers on employment while holding neighborhood quality fixed at its current level, arguing this isolates the voucher effect independent of relocation. In practice, vouchers often enable families to move to higher-opportunity neighborhoods, which affects employment.
claim: If housing vouchers were offered while neighborhood quality remained unchanged, employment would increase.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: X → M → Y; attempting to fix M while changing X creates an ill-defined counterfactual unless mediation assumptions are made explicit.
key_insight: Holding a mediator fixed while changing the treatment can create an incoherent counterfactual world.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if you want the total effect of X on Y: Do not fix M; compare Y under different X values.

wise_refusal: I can’t answer the “hold M fixed” counterfactual without clarifying whether M is post-treatment and specifying the mediation estimand and assumptions.
gold_rationale:
This is Confounder–Mediator Error (Mediator Fixing Error).
 M lies on the causal pathway from X to Y. The proposed counterfactual “change X while holding M fixed” is generally not identifiable from standard observational data and can be logically inconsistent with how M would respond to X.
 Fixing M can create a counterfactual world that is incompatible with the causal system, leading to biased or undefined effects.
 Conclusion: The proposed counterfactual is INVALID unless you define a well-posed mediation estimand and justify strong assumptions (or perform a suitable intervention on M).

scenario: A manager considers whether overtime work affects promotion decisions. In this organization, employees are assigned overtime after leadership already views them as promotion candidates, using overtime as a test. Overtime increases after early promotion signals appear.
claim: If Alex had not worked so much overtime, Alex would not have been promoted.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: Y (or early Y) → X; treating X as a cause leads to outcome-dependent counterfactuals.
key_insight: Counterfactuals are not valid when the “cause” is actually reacting to the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did promotion decision (or early indicators of it) occur before changes in working overtime, potentially causing X rather than being caused by it?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if X clearly occurs before Y and can be intervened on: Then the counterfactual is meaningful and can be analyzed with a causal model.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if Y (or early Y signals) drives X: Then interpret the relationship as reverse causation; redesign the study to capture pre-outcome X.

wise_refusal: I can’t assess the counterfactual without a clear timeline showing whether working overtime precedes promotion decision and whether X can be manipulated independently of Y.
gold_rationale:
This is L3 Reverse Causation (Outcome-dependent Worlds).
 The setup suggests X is chosen or changes in response to the outcome (or strong early signals of the outcome), so imagining “set X differently” may implicitly change the underlying situation that produced Y.
 If X is downstream of Y (or of early manifestations of Y), naive counterfactual comparisons can be ill-posed or misleading.
 Conclusion: The proposed counterfactual claim is INVALID unless timing is clarified and a causal ordering that makes X antecedent to Y is justified.

The algorithm influences what content users see, which affects user retention, posting behavior, and future content production. These changes alter future recommendation data and exposure patterns over time.

 Changing X alters the system state F over time, and F then changes future behaviors and outcomes, creating different trajectories under different counterfactual policies.
 A static comparison that ignores how the environment adapts can misstate “what would have happened” under an alternative X.
 Conclusion: The counterfactual claim is CONDITIONAL: you need a dynamic causal model (or simulation/longitudinal design) that accounts for feedback.

scenario: A large protest occurred after a primary organizer led a march. Multiple groups were prepared to take over leadership. If the primary organizer had been arrested the night before, a backup organizer might have led an alternative march that still resulted in a protest.
claim: If the primary protest organizer had been arrested the night before, the protest would not have occurred.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Two sufficient causes for Y; removing one may not change Y because the other would occur.
key_insight: Observed causation does not imply counterfactual dependence when multiple sufficient causes can produce the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: If arresting the primary organizer were prevented, what alternative cause would have been most likely to produce Y, and would it occur earlier or later?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Answer if no other sufficient cause exists: Then preventing X would prevent Y, so X is a but-for cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Answer if alternative sufficient causes exist: Y may still occur without X; you need a structural model of competing causes and timing.

wise_refusal: I can’t decide whether X is a but-for cause without specifying competing causes and their timing; otherwise the counterfactual is underdetermined.
gold_rationale:
This is L3 Preemption (Early Preemption).
 There are multiple sufficient causal paths to Y. Even if X occurs in the observed world, removing X in the counterfactual world may not change Y because an alternative cause would produce Y instead.
 Attribution requires modeling which cause would have fired in the absence of X (counterfactual dependence), not just observing that X happened.
 Conclusion: The naive statement “X caused Y” is CONDITIONAL; it depends on whether Y counterfactually depends on X given competing causes.

scenario: A cancer screening test detects tumors earlier. Patients diagnosed via screening live 5 years longer after diagnosis than those diagnosed by symptoms. Hospital promotes screening as “adding 5 years to life.”
claim: Routine screening increases patients’ actual lifespan by about five years.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → earlier diagnosis; earlier diagnosis inflates Y without changing death time
key_insight: Screening can start the survival clock earlier without extending total lifespan (lead-time/length bias).
hidden_timestamp: Did screened patients actually die later, or were they just diagnosed earlier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If screening only shifts diagnosis earlier: The longer post-diagnosis survival is an artifact of lead-time/length bias, not longer life.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If screening delays death (mortality falls): Then screening could provide a real survival benefit.

wise_refusal: Longer survival after diagnosis does not prove longer life. Screening can move the diagnosis date earlier without delaying death. We need evidence that screening reduces mortality or increases age at death, not just post-diagnosis survival.
gold_rationale: Lead Time Bias (Survival Measurement Artifact) applies: Screening can start the survival clock earlier without extending total lifespan (lead-time/length bias).

scenario: A clinic reviews outcomes for patients whose cancers were detected through routine screening versus those detected after symptoms. Screened patients appear to survive five years longer when survival is measured from the diagnosis date.
claim: Because screening finds cancer earlier, it adds five years to patients’ lifespan.
label: NO
causal_structure: Earlier detection shifts the diagnosis timestamp forward; survival-from-diagnosis increases even if the death date is unchanged.
key_insight: A longer time from diagnosis to death can be a measurement artifact when diagnosis occurs earlier.
hidden_timestamp: Did screening actually delay death (older age at death), or did it only move the diagnosis date earlier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If death occurs at the same age and only diagnosis is earlier, the five-year ‘benefit’ is lead-time/length bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If screening reduces mortality or shifts death to later ages, then screening could provide a real survival benefit.

wise_refusal: You can’t conclude screening adds years to life from post-diagnosis survival alone. We need evidence of reduced mortality or later death, not an earlier start of the clock.
gold_rationale: Lead-time bias inflates measured survival by starting the survival clock earlier; the proper comparison is age at death or mortality rates, not survival time since diagnosis.

scenario: People who take vitamin D supplements have 30% lower rates of depression. A wellness company markets vitamin D as “nature’s antidepressant.”
claim: Taking the supplement directly prevents depression.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (healthy-user/SES confounding)
key_insight: Supplement users differ systematically (health behaviors, SES), so the association is confounded.
hidden_timestamp: Do supplement users differ in baseline health, activity, or socioeconomic status?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If confounders explain group differences: The association is non-causal; X is a marker of Z which drives Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If effects persist after adjustment/RCT: Then X may have an independent causal effect.

wise_refusal: This is an observational association and is likely confounded by healthy-user and socioeconomic differences. Without randomization or strong adjustment for baseline lifestyle and SES, we cannot attribute lower depression rates to the supplement itself.
gold_rationale: Confounding (Healthy User Correlation) applies: Supplement users differ systematically (health behaviors, SES), so the association is confounded.

scenario: A cross-sectional survey finds that people who opt into a wellness activity (e.g., supplements, mindfulness workshops, resilience training) report lower depression than non-participants.
claim: Participating in the wellness activity directly prevents depression.
label: NO
causal_structure: Self-selection into wellness participation correlates with health consciousness, resources, and baseline mental health—factors that also affect depression.
key_insight: The association can be explained by healthy-user and socioeconomic confounding rather than a causal program effect.
hidden_timestamp: After controlling for baseline mental health, SES, and lifestyle, does the association persist?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants are healthier or wealthier at baseline, the observed difference is confounding (healthy-user bias), not causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the effect remains within matched groups or under random assignment, the intervention may have a true causal benefit.

wise_refusal: Voluntary wellness participation is heavily confounded. Without randomization or strong adjustment for baseline differences, we cannot attribute lower depression to the activity itself.
gold_rationale: Healthy-user bias and SES differences can fully produce the observed correlation; causal claims require controlling confounders or randomized evidence.

scenario: Hospital A has a 95% surgery survival rate while Hospital B has 90%. A patient chooses Hospital A as “clearly better.”
claim: The higher overall survival rate proves Hospital A is better for all patients.
label: NO
causal_structure: Case mix/severity (Z) differs by hospital; aggregation can reverse within-stratum effects
key_insight: Raw averages can mislead when hospitals treat different severity mixes (Simpson’s paradox).
hidden_timestamp: How do outcomes compare within the same severity/risk category?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcomes reverse within relevant strata: The aggregate comparison is misleading (Simpson’s paradox).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If one option wins within every stratum: Then the aggregate ranking likely reflects a real difference.

wise_refusal: Raw outcome rates ignore case mix. If one hospital treats sicker patients, its overall survival can look worse even if it performs better within each severity group. We need risk-adjusted or stratified comparisons.
gold_rationale: Simpsons Paradox (Case Mix Confounding) applies: Raw averages can mislead when hospitals treat different severity mixes (Simpson’s paradox).

scenario: Two institutions are compared using a single overall success rate. Institution A looks better on the aggregate metric, but Institution B serves a higher proportion of high-risk cases.
claim: Institution A is better than Institution B because its overall success rate is higher.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate rates mix different case mixes; stratifying by baseline risk can reverse the apparent advantage.
key_insight: Overall averages can mislead when subgroup composition differs; compare within strata or risk-adjust.
hidden_timestamp: When you compare within the same risk/severity strata, does the ranking reverse?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If B outperforms within each comparable stratum, the aggregate advantage of A is Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If A remains better within each stratum, then the aggregate result likely reflects true quality differences.

wise_refusal: Raw aggregate rates are not comparable across groups with different baseline risk. We need stratified or risk-adjusted outcomes before concluding one is better.
gold_rationale: Simpson’s paradox occurs when subgroup distributions differ; conclusions should be drawn from stratified/risk-adjusted comparisons, not unadjusted aggregates.

scenario: Children born in winter months have slightly higher rates of schizophrenia. A re- searcher proposes: “Seasonal infections during pregnancy cause schizophrenia.”
claim: Seasonal infections during pregnancy cause schizophrenia.
label: NO
causal_structure: Multiple confounders (Z) drive both X and Y; aggregate correlation ≠ individual causation
key_insight: Small population-level correlations don’t identify individual-level mechanisms (ecological fallacy).
hidden_timestamp: Does the association hold within matched individuals after controlling for key confounders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the pattern is only at the group level: You cannot infer individual causation from aggregate correlations.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the effect holds in individual-level matched data: Then a causal mechanism becomes more plausible.

wise_refusal: A weak population-level correlation does not identify a causal mechanism for individuals. Many confounders (SES, conception timing, reporting, diagnostic practices) can generate the pattern, so causal claims about infections require stronger evidence.
gold_rationale: Ecological Fallacy (Aggregate Pattern Overinterpretation) applies: Small population-level correlations don’t identify individual-level mechanisms (ecological fallacy).

scenario: A regional dataset shows that areas with higher exposure prevalence also have higher outcome prevalence. A report concludes the exposure causes the outcome in each individual resident.
claim: The area-level exposure causes the outcome for individuals living in that area.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group-level associations can arise from population composition and confounders; they do not identify individual-level causal mechanisms.
key_insight: You cannot infer individual causation from aggregated correlations without individual-level analysis.
hidden_timestamp: Does the relationship hold at the individual level after controlling for SES, access, and other confounders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level analysis (with confounders controlled) removes the association, the claim is an ecological fallacy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a controlled individual-level analysis still shows an effect, the exposure may be causal—but the aggregate result alone is insufficient evidence.

wise_refusal: Aggregate patterns do not justify individual causal claims. Individual-level data and confounder control are required before concluding causation.
gold_rationale: Ecological fallacy: inferring individual-level causation from group-level associations; composition/confounding can drive regional correlations.

scenario: A patient’s chronic pain improved after trying the 5th treatment. Their doctor notes: “You’re a responder to Treatment E. We should have tried it first.”

gold_rationale: Regression To Mean (Sequential Trial Artifact) applies: Improvement after many failures is often regression to the mean, not evidence the last treatment worked.

wise_refusal: A single improvement after an extreme baseline is weak evidence. Without matched controls (or repeated on/off evidence), we cannot separate natural fluctuation from treatment effect.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean predicts that extreme measurements move toward average on re-measurement; causal attribution requires controls matched on baseline extremity.

scenario: Patients reporting severe migraines (Y) were found to have consumed chocolate (X) recently. These patients were in the ‘Prodrome’ phase (Z) of a migraine attack.
claim: Eating chocolate triggers migraines.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X(prodrome causes craving)
key_insight: Cravings are symptoms, not triggers
hidden_timestamp: Did the craving (X) startafterthe biological onset of the attack (Z)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(Prodrome causes craving): The migraine’s prodrome phase (Z) causes cravings for sweet/fatty foods (X). Chocolate is asymptomof the impending migraine, not a cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(Chocolate triggers migraine): If chocolate was consumed days before prodrome onset, it may be a trigger.

wise_refusal: This is classic protopathic bias. The prodrome phase causes food cravings before pain onset. Chocolate consumption may be a symptom of the impending attack, not a trigger. Please clarify the timing of consumption relative to prodrome onset.” 2.12

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Conscientiousness Confounds: Flossing (X) is a marker for conscientiousness per- sonality trait (Z). Conscientious people do everything right (exercise, diet, don’t smoke), extending life (Y). Flossing itself may add nothing. 10

scenario: Seniors who got the Flu Shot (X) had lower all-cause mortality (Y) during winter. These seniors were mobile enough to travel to the clinic (Z).
claim: Flu vaccination reduces all-cause winter mortality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X, Y(baseline health determines both)
key_insight: Vaccine recipients are healthier at baseline
hidden_timestamp: Did the mortality difference existbeforeflu season started?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Frailty Confounds: Those who skipped the shot were too frail (Z) to leave home and more likely to die (Y) regardless of flu. The shot (X) is a marker of baseline health.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Shot is Protective: If the mortality gap appears only during flu season and disap- pears in summer, the shot has specific protective effect.

wise_refusal: Frailty bias inflates vaccine effectiveness. Seniors who get vaccinated are health- ier at baseline. We need pre-season mortality data to separate frailty selection from vaccine effect.” 2.15
gold_rationale: Selection (Frailty Bias) applies: Vaccine recipients are healthier at baseline

claim: Medication M improves health because it stabilizes blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → overcorrection → Z
key_insight: “Stable” may mean dangerously low
hidden_timestamp: Did the dizziness (Z) correlate with pressure dips below normal range?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Overtreatment: The “stability” (Y) is actually dangerous hypotension. Dizziness (Z) signals the drug (X) is overcorrecting. The outcome is harm, not benefit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Side Effect: Dizziness (Z) is an independent side effect, unrelated to the BP mech- anism.

scenario: Patients undergoing Knee Replacement (X) reported a 50% reduction in pain (Y). These patients also adhered to a strict Physical Therapy regimen (Z).
claim: Knee replacement surgery caused the pain reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z → Y(PT as mediator) orZ → Yindependently
key_insight: PT may work without surgery
hidden_timestamp: Did the patient start the PT regimen (Z)beforethe surgery date?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(PT is Confounder): PT (Z) may have reduced pain (Y) independently. Surgery (X) may be unnecessary if PT alone works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(PT is Mediator): Surgery (X) requires PT (Z) for recovery. The surgery is the root cause; PT is the mechanism of benefit.

wise_refusal: Co-interventions confound surgical outcomes. If PT began before surgery, PT may deserve credit. If PT is mandatory post-surgery, it is a mediator. Please clarify whether PT preceded or followed the operation.” 2.18
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Co-Intervention Confounding) applies: PT may work without surgery

scenario: Participants taking the experimental painkiller (X) reported 30% less pain (Y). The trial was not double-blind, and the doctor told them it was ‘very strong’ (Z).
claim: The experimental drug reduced pain by 30%.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y(expectation drives subjective outcome)
key_insight: Unblinded trials confound pharmacology with psychology
hidden_timestamp: Did the pain relief (Y) startbeforethe drug could biologically be absorbed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Placebo: The doctor’s suggestion (Z) created expectation of relief. If pain dropped before pharmacokinetics allow (instant relief), it is purely placebo.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Drug Works: If relief coincides with expected drug absorption timing, the chemical has effect.

wise_refusal: Unblinded trials confound drug effects with placebo effects. The doctor’s sugges- tion biases patient reporting. Without a blinded control group, we cannot separate pharmacology from expectation.” 2.19
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Expectation Bias / Placebo) applies: Unblinded trials confound pharmacology with psychology

scenario: Among patients who completed (Z) a 12-month clinical trial, those on the experimental drug (X) had better outcomes (Y) than those on placebo.
claim: Among trial completers, the experimental drug is superior to placebo.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z←Y(dropout reasons differ by arm)
key_insight: Completers are a biased sample
hidden_timestamp: Are we conditioning on trial completion (Z)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Patients drop out of trials due to side effects (drug arm) or lack of efficacy (placebo arm). Conditioning on completion (Z) excludes drug patients who had bad reactions and placebo patients who deteriorated. The “completers” are a biased sample. The drug may look better because its failures dropped out.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Per-protocol analysis conditions on completion, which is a collider. Patients drop out for different reasons in each arm. Intention-to-treat analysis (including dropouts) is required for valid comparison.” 2.20
gold_rationale: Collider (Per-Protocol vs. Intention-to-Treat) applies: Completers are a biased sample

scenario: Among hospitalized patients (Z), those with Disease A (X) have lower rates of Disease B (Y) than expected from population data.
claim: Disease A protects against Disease B.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z←Y(both diseases cause hospitalization)
key_insight: Hospital-based studies create spurious correlations
hidden_timestamp: Are A and B independent causes of hospitalization?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Both Disease A and Disease B independently cause hospitalization (Z). Among hospitalized patients, having A “explains away” why they are hospitalized, making B less likely conditional onZ. This is spurious negative correlation. In the general population, A and B may be independent or even positively correlated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Hospital-based studies condition on admission, which is a collider when multiple diseases cause admission. The apparent negative association between diseases A and B is Berkson’s Paradox, not a biological relationship.” 2.21
gold_rationale: Collider (Berkson’s Paradox) applies: Hospital-based studies create spurious correlations

scenario: Among published studies (Z), Drug D (X) shows a 40% improvement over placebo (Y).
claim: Drug D improves outcomes by ~40% compared with placebo.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y → Z(positive results get published)
key_insight: The file drawer contains null results
hidden_timestamp: Are we only seeing studies that reached publication?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Studies are published (Z) if they show positive results (Y) or are methodolog- ically important. Null results go in the file drawer. The 40% effect is inflated by publication bias. The true effect, including unpublished trials, is likely smaller.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Published literature conditions on publication, which selects for positive results. Meta-analyses of published studies overestimate treatment effects. We need data from trial registries to include unpublished null results.” 2.22
gold_rationale: Collider (Publication Bias) applies: The file drawer contains null results

wise_refusal: This is a preemption case. The heart attack was already lethal before the overdose was administered. scenario: A patient with cancer (90% fatal within 5 years) receives a new drug (30% effective at inducing remission). The patient survives 10 years. The patient thanks the drug. Skeptics note: “10% of untreated patients survive anyway.” 32
claim: The drug definitely saved this patient’s life.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Probabilistic counterfactual attribution
key_insight: PS = P(would survive only with drug — survived with drug)
hidden_timestamp: What are the baseline survival rate without drug and the survival rate with drug?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If P(survival|drug)=0.40 and P(survival|no drug)=0.10: Probability the drug was sufficient given survival is (0.40−0.10)/0.40 ≈ 75%.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the baseline survival without drug is close to with-drug: Then the probability the drug was sufficient is low; survival likely would have occurred anyway.

wise_refusal: This requires Probability of Sufficiency, not simple correlation. Given the sur- vival rates, there’s approximately 75% probability the drug was causally responsible for this pa- tient’s survival, and 25% probability they were among the 10% who would have survived regardless.”
gold_rationale: Counterfactual (Probability of Sufficiency (PS)) applies: PS = P(would survive only with drug — survived with drug)

scenario: A patient’s cancer was diagnosed 6 months late due to a radiologist’s error. At time of actual diagnosis, survival probability was 30%. Expert testimony: “If diagnosed on time, survival probability would have been 70%.”
claim: The 6‑month delay reduced survival probability by 40 percentage points.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Delay → ∆P(survival)
key_insight: Harm quantified as change in probability, not binary outcome
hidden_timestamp: What were the survival probabilities with timely diagnosis versus the 6‑month delay?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If timely diagnosis yields 0.70 survival vs 0.30 delayed: Harm is a 40 percentage-point loss of chance (0.70−0.30).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If survival probabilities are similar: Then delay caused little to no loss of chance.

wise_refusal: The harm from the delay is the reduction in survival probability: 70%→30% = 40 percentage points of lost chance. Whether the patient ultimately survives or dies, the delay caused a measurable reduction in their survival odds.”
gold_rationale: Counterfactual (Temporal / Timing Effects) applies: Harm quantified as change in probability, not binary outcome
